pr_title: Using symlink with IPC server so that socket filepath is short

timeline.bodyText: how is this going to work given that stuff is running in their own work dirs?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: The components will read the absolute path from the env variable. This symlink is only being sent to IPC server.
replies.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: The clients don't have the same path problem?
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I was thinking clients can control to create a symlink themselves if needed because any of the generated code does not configure socket options for them. The client themselves create the socket options, so this can be more of on need basis. However we can set relative link in the env variable but I just thought having relative link can be undeterministic (if the assumption of client having CWD as expected is not true). For integration tests in kernel it will be not true I think.
replies.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: We set the CWD, so we can make that assumption
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.message: Using symlink with IPC server so that socket filepath is short
Using symlink with IPC server so that socket filepath is short
Using symlink with IPC server so that socket filepath is short
Making symlink to nucleus root rather than to the socket file
Fixing deletion of nucleus root path symlink

timeline.bodyText: you're assuming that the CWD of the nucleus is the root which isn't necessarily true. You should use an absolute path when creating and deleting the symlinks to make sure they're all pointing to the proper location.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: No I am not assuming that, whatever the CWD, the symlink is being created in that directory and pointing to absolute path. I can delete the symlink during close to ensure that whatever symlink was created get deleted on server shutdown.
replies.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText:
The symlink wont be in the correct place though!
If the CWD of the kernel is /root/home/GG, then the symlink could be pointing to the right thing, but the relative path ../../nucleusRoot/socket will not be correct
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
The relative path I am using is ../../ipcEventStreamServer.socket
Irrespective of where the symlink is it should be able to get to that file in the nucleus root (assuming '../../' takes the component to kernel root)
Is this assumption wrong? Is the CWD of component relative to kernel's CWD or kernel's root?
replies.author: abanthiy

replies.bodyText: There are 2 relative paths that you're using. ./nucleusRoot/ipcEventStreamServer.socket is this path, which is relative to the kernel's CWD and not the component's CWDs. The kernel's CWD is not necessarily the root. Use nucleusPaths to get a proper path
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: NUCLEUS_ROOT_PATH_SYMLINK must be an absolute path or it needs to be correctly relative
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: As discussed offline, having as absolute path does not solve the underlying problem. The concern was that we are writing outside of nucleus root which is reduced by putting in a check to create symlink only when necessary.
replies.author: abanthiy

timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: this won't be closed if the test fails. Use try with resources or try-finally
timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.message: Adding check to create symlink only when absolute path is greater than 108 chars
Shortening the filename for ipc server socket

timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: The client still has option to create a symlink themselves and solve teh issue. I don;t want to take that away from them by not starting the server
replies.author: abanthiy
